title: The Impact of Sentiment on Crypto Markets
keyQuestions: What does “sentiment” mean in crypto, and why does it move price so quickly?
Which sentiment signals are most useful (social, derivatives, on-chain, attention)?
How do you separate unique interest from repeated noise and bot amplification?
How can you use sentiment without getting trapped by narratives and crowding?
How do you protect your informational footprint while rotating positions?
quickSteps: Start with a thesis, then use sentiment as a wind check—not a standalone strategy.
Track social + derivatives + on-chain together: unique voices, funding, skew, and flows.
Size smaller when signals are loud and late; scale only when evidence stays aligned.
Pre-write exits using objective thresholds (funding, inflows, skew flips).
Protect privacy and metadata: keep routes simple, custody short, and data sharing minimal.

issueRouting.start: I want to use sentiment signals without becoming exit liquidity

branches.if: I’m trading short-term moves and want cleaner entries
then: Prefer early, aligned signals: unique accounts rising + neutral funding + steady volume
Avoid chasing extreme funding and euphoric language; wait for better entries
Use explicit exit rules and respect them

branches.if: I’m managing risk during volatile periods
then: Treat sentiment extremes as caution flags; reduce size and tighten risk
Confirm with positioning proxies (funding, basis, skew) and liquidity conditions
Avoid forcing trades when time windows and congestion are hostile

branches.if: I care about privacy and strategy leakage while rotating
then: Minimize unnecessary identity exposure; don’t share what isn’t required
Keep research and execution hygiene separate where practical
Prefer routes that reduce metadata exhaust when privacy matters

riskNotes: Sentiment tools are binoculars, not trading systems—use them with risk limits, not vibes.
Bots, sarcasm, and selection bias can break naive sentiment models—cross-check independent sources.
Reflexivity can double-count directionality: rising price can cause positive sentiment, not only the reverse.
Protect your footprint: avoid over-sharing routes and timing if privacy or strategy matters.
